posts.name: Crossle86
posts.cooked:
When using Shuffleboard, the OpenJDK binary consumes a lot of cpu. After starting the DS  and having the Shuffleboard loaded, the cpu consumption is high, but things seem to function acceptably.

However, if we close the lid on the  DS  laptop and then later open it back up, the cpu consumption of OpenJDK binary is even higher to the point the DS PC is unusable. This does  not happen with every close and open of the lid but most of the time. When this occurs, we  have to kill the shuffleboard and reload and it works until next lid close.

posts.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
posts.cooked:
Crossle86:

However, if we close the lid on the DS laptop and then later open it back up, the cpu consumption of OpenJDK binary is even higher to the point the DS PC is unusable. This does not happen with every close and open of the lid but most of the time. When this occurs, we have to kill the shuffleboard and reload and it works until next lid close.

This is familiar.  A couple years back our laptops really struggled with Shuffleboard.  And resetting DS, at least between matches is good practice.  Maybe just get in habit of closing it before sleeping the computer.
posts.display_username: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)

posts.name: Crossle86
posts.cooked: The problem with that solution is that the laptop is closed on the way to a match and then opened at the field. It may be closed again when leaving the staging area for the team position at the field wall and then opened again. We don’t want the laptop open when moving our driver station. We don’t want to be closing/restarting the DS code when on the field either. Note that this problem surfaced for us after the cancellation of 2020 season, so we have not been to a competition with this problem in play, but it concerns me.

reply_to_user.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked: What version of shuffleboard are you using?

posts.name: Blake Bourque
posts.cooked: Shuffleboard has been hogging resources for us too. Definitely seems to be worse when we have lots of graphs going.

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked:
techplex:

Definitely seems to be worse when we have lots of graphs going.

Yep. It used to be a lot worse too. We switched the plotting backend for 2021: Change GraphWidget to ChartFX (#657) · wpilibsuite/shuffleboard@824258e · GitHub

link_counts.title: Change GraphWidget to ChartFX (#657) · wpilibsuite/shuffleboard@824258e · GitHub

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: My general recommendation is to use Glass if you want plots.

posts.name: Crossle86
posts.cooked: I will have to check that when I am next in the lab, but its the at least the version released at start of 2021. Note we dont graph or do anything spectacular, pretty vanilla use of SB.

posts.name: Dalton Smith
posts.cooked: Shuffleboard is one of the “highest resouce” demanding thing we distribute (beaten only be wpimath). Also, sleep mode is wonky in all sorts of applications, it’s not a highly tested scenario. I wish I could say this bug will get looked into, but shuffleboard is minimally maintained at this point in time.

posts.name: Crossle86
posts.cooked: Is  that because we are getting another new dashboard (glass) technology in 2022?

posts.name: Dalton Smith
posts.cooked: Partially. It’s more to due with there is no active developer for it. WPILib is a community/volunteer driven project. As such, volunteers come and go.

posts.name: Crossle86
posts.cooked: So I  finally got into the lab and we  are running SB 2021.1.2, so that is old. Question: I recently updated the gradlerio version to 2021.3.1 to update the libraries used by VSSCode. Is gradlerio supposed to update the tools as well? Does not appear to have done so. if gradlerio does not update the tools, what is the “approved” way to update the tools? Run the WpiLib installer again?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Yes, run the installer to get all of the updated tools installed.  This also ensures all of the dependencies are installed offline so you don’t need internet connectivity to build and deploy.

posts.name: Crossle86
posts.cooked: So what components does gradlerio update when you change the version number?

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked: It just updates itself, which makes it use the latest WPILib libraries. However, it grabs these from the internet, which makes it possible to run into issues at competition. Which is why we recommend just running the installer again, as this will install local copies of everything.

posts.name: Crossle86
posts.cooked:
So this all seems a bit rough. If it is  recommended to install wpilib updates from the  ISO, it is required to update the gradlerio version to access those updates?

I thought that gradlerio would use local cached libraries if present and only download libraries if not present…and once downloaded they would be present thus avoiding the issue when internet is not available.

I am trying to understand and document for our team the nuances of keeping things updated.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Once you install the update from the ISO, and update your project, GR will use the (upgraded) local cached libraries.  If you don’t install the ISO, you can still update your project to the new GR, it will just need to pull those libraries from the internet.  So the recommendation is to upgrade using the ISO and then update your project to use what you installed.
